title: Jianlei Han 韩剑雷
raw: --- title: Jianlei Han 韩剑雷 --- Welcome to [Jianlei Han](https://researchers.mq.edu.au/en/persons/jianlei-han) 's website! # Contact Senior Lecturer in Finance Macquarie University Business School Macquarie University ✉ jianlei.han@mq.edu.au 🌐 https://researchers.mq.edu.au/en/persons/jianlei-han https://github.com/jianleihan89 🅶 [Google Scholar](https://scholar.google.com.au/citations?user=dcxEat4AAAAJ&hl=en) # Research Interest Fintech, Defi, Corporate Culture, Chinese Capital Market # Education -Ph.D. in Finance, University of Queensland -M.Phil. in Statistics, Renmin University of China -B.A. in Statistics, Tongji University # Working Papers --**Trust in DeFi: An empirical study of the decentralized exchange**, with [Shiyang Huang](https://www.hkubs.hku.hk/people/shiyang-huang/) and [Zhuo Zhong](https://www.joe-zh.com/) We empirically study the role of the decentralized cryptocurrency exchange (DEX) in affecting cryptocurrency trading. We propose several hypotheses regarding the effect of DEX and find evidence consistent with a learning channel. That is, investors trust the DEX: DEX’s userbase information affects investor trading on the centralized cryptocurrency exchange (CEX). This effect intensifies during instances of market manipulation––“wash trading”—on the CEX or when investors have more concerns about it. Conversely, CEX’s userbase doesn’t reciprocally impact CEX trading. Using the “yield-farming” program launch as quasi-exogenous shocks, we confirm DEX’s causal impact on CEX trading. Our study highlights that the DEX can foster efficient, transparent trading structures where trustworthy centralized mechanisms are impractical or costly. [SSRN Link](https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3896461)

Research Interest

Fintech, Defi, Corporate Culture, Chinese Capital Market

Education

-Ph.D. in Finance, University of Queensland
-M.Phil. in Statistics, Renmin University of China
-B.A. in Statistics, Tongji University

Working Papers

–Trust in DeFi: An empirical study of the decentralized exchange, with Shiyang Huang and Zhuo Zhong
We empirically study the role of the decentralized cryptocurrency exchange (DEX) in affecting cryptocurrency trading. We propose several hypotheses regarding the effect of DEX and find evidence consistent with a learning channel. That is, investors trust the DEX: DEX’s userbase information affects investor trading on the centralized cryptocurrency exchange (CEX). This effect intensifies during instances of market manipulation––“wash trading”—on the CEX or when investors have more concerns about it. Conversely, CEX’s userbase doesn’t reciprocally impact CEX trading. Using the “yield-farming” program launch as quasi-exogenous shocks, we confirm DEX’s causal impact on CEX trading. Our study highlights that the DEX can foster efficient, transparent trading structures where trustworthy centralized mechanisms are impractical or costly.
SSRN Link

Working Papers

–Trust in DeFi: An empirical study of the decentralized exchange, with Shiyang Huang and Zhuo Zhong
We empirically study the role of the decentralized cryptocurrency exchange (DEX) in affecting cryptocurrency trading. We propose several hypotheses regarding the effect of DEX and find evidence consistent with a learning channel. That is, investors trust the DEX: DEX’s userbase information affects investor trading on the centralized cryptocurrency exchange (CEX). This effect intensifies during instances of market manipulation––“wash trading”—on the CEX or when investors have more concerns about it. Conversely, CEX’s userbase doesn’t reciprocally impact CEX trading. Using the “yield-farming” program launch as quasi-exogenous shocks, we confirm DEX’s causal impact on CEX trading. Our study highlights that the DEX can foster efficient, transparent trading structures where trustworthy centralized mechanisms are impractical or costly.
